title: Lights On
description:
Bask in exclusive new works developed by leading Brisbane companies and creative artists emerging from isolation.  

Lights On at Brisbane Powerhouse is a curated series of bespoke shows; a limited season created for small audiences and a re-imagined venue.

Be the first to experience the buzz of live performance again and revel in shows by QMusic featuring Robert Forster, Darren Halna, Sycco and Minor Premiers,  Queensland Symphony Orchestra + Tom Thum, Circa Ensemble, Queensland Ballet and Club Briefs.

It’s time to reconnect and shine a light on our extraordinary local arts community.
eventVenuMapLink: Brisbane Powerhouse, 119 Lamington Street, New Farm
eventBookingSite: Book now via Brisbane Powerhouse website.

title: The Storytellers: Step into the stories of our city
description:
Uncover Brisbane’s histories, myths and tales as told by the storytellers of our city.

Featuring new stories by Victoria Carless, Simon Cleary, Matthew Condon, Trent Dalton, Nick Earls, Benjamin Law, Hugh Lunn, Kate Morton and Ellen van Neerven, The Storytellers creates an immersive and interactive experience combining historical objects, artworks, and written and narrated histories to share Brisbane’s many identities.

10am-5pm daily, 10am-7pm Fridays

Location: Gallery 1
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City
eventBookingSite: Book free Museum entry.

title: Brisbane City Hall LEGO Build
description:
Come help us celebrate a major birthday! City Hall is 100 years old and renowned LEGO® builder Ben Craig, also known as The Brick Builder has undertaken a monumental project!

This is a free pop-up event.

Ben has rebuilt Brisbane City Hall from the ground up, using over 40,000 LEGO® Bricks. This City Hall LEGO® replica includes the building’s iconic features, from the prominent entryway, to the Clock Tower and copper dome, with a large internal viewing space exploring stories and moments from the iconic building’s history.
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City
eventBookingSite: Find out more.

title: Artist-in-residence: Kim Ah Sam
description:
Kim Ah Sam is a Kuku Yalanji/ Kalkadoon artist working across drypoint, etching, weaving, printmaking and paper making. An abiding theme of her art practice is investigating ways of spiritually reconnecting with her father’s Country, Kalkadoon in North-West Queensland.   

Using traditional and repurposed materials, Kim develops methods of working that demonstrate how the two can meet in a contemporary context. Kim’s weaving process is often collaborative, involving storytelling and knowledge-sharing, a practice which is deeply embedded in First Nations communities Australia-wide.  

Exhibition: Daily 10am-5pm, until 7pm Fridays

Location: Adelaide Stree Pavilion

Visit Kim Saturdays and Sundays until 6 September.
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City
eventBookingSite: Book free Museum entry.

title: Faces of Brisbane - recent portraiture acquisitions
description:
Faces of Brisbane showcases eight portraits recently acquired by Museum of Brisbane. As these artworks demonstrate, artists continue to return to portraiture as a genre that, despite its traditional origins, constantly evolves. The contemporary artists in this exhibition experiment with portraiture as a means of exploring identity, history and relationships. It is a genre which speaks to our enduring interest in one another, and the importance of feeling connected.

The portraits on display depict a range of individuals with different stories, from family members and friends to historical figures and local artists. The artworks explore contemporary approaches to capturing individual and collective identities, helping us to share the many stories of the city and its people.  

Location: Dome Gallery
Daily: 10am-5pm, until 7pm Fridays
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City
eventBookingSite: Book free museum entry online.

title: Elizabeth Willing: Blank stares
description:
Come and explore Blank stares, a site-specific collage installation by Elizabeth Willing, composed of food images from vintage cookbooks!

Elizabeth Willing is a Brisbane-based artist who uses food as her primary subject and material. For more than 10 years, Elizabeth has created artworks generated by the act of consumption, participatory installations, ephemeral edible sculptures, paintings and experimental dining events which engage audiences through smell, taste, sight and touch.

Elizabeth launched Museum of Brisbane’s 2020 Artist-in-Residence program from 3 – 27 February 2020. During her time working in The Studio, Elizabeth created several new works including this site-specific collage installation using food images from vintage cookbooks.

Times: Daily 10am-5pm, until 7pm Fridays

Location: The Hallway
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City
eventBookingSite: Book free museum entry

title: 97.3FM COVID-19 time capsule
description:
Come and see a curated selection of artefacts donated by Brisbane locals, capturing Brisbane’s COVID-19 experience.

From puzzles and paper hugs to toilet paper hoarding and hand sanitiser, Museum of Brisbane and 97.3FM have teamed up to capture the chaos, creativity and cultural phenomena that punctuated Brisbane’s COVID-19 experience in early 2020 with a very special time capsule.

Carefully curated to capture the highs and lows of our city’s unique lockdown experience, this repository comprises of 28 artefacts donated by Brisbane locals to seize a moment in time.

Featuring generous contributions from Lord Mayor Adrian Schrinner, Wally Lewis, Trent Dalton, the 97.3FM team and many more, take a peek at history in the making before it is sealed away in our archives for 20 years.

Times: Daily from 10am-5pm, until 7pm Fridays
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City
eventBookingSite: Book free museum entry

title: RAZZLE DAZZLE - Outdoor Gallery
description:
From 10 August to 22 November 2020, experience Brisbane City Council's Outdoor Gallery RAZZLE DAZZLE exhibition curated by McCarthySwann Projects curators Amy-Clare McCarthy and Kieran Swann, including a number of talks, tours and engagements.

RAZZLE DAZZLE considers the nature of public space and individuals within it - particularly people who for different reasons, may feel hyper-visible or invisible. Considering ideas of identity, spectacle, and camouflage, the artists included use patterning, colour, or adornment to either hide, exaggerate, or transform.

Brisbane City Council's Outdoor Gallery transforms Brisbane's laneways and city streets into imaginative, curious and engaging spaces. Comprising light boxes, banners, vitrines and evening projections, the Outdoor Gallery displays art outside in city streets, instead of inside on gallery walls. Recently, the Outdoor Gallery has grown to now include art projections at Howard Smith Wharves.

title: Bauhaus Now: art+design+architecture
description:
**This event has been cancelled.** Bauhaus Now brings to life the little-known story of how revolutionary ideas of the Weimar Republic in Germany influenced modernist art, design and architecture in Brisbane and Australia. The exhibition reveals the migrant and refugee contribution to Australian life and art history in the inter-war period and post-Second World War years.

The famous Bauhaus school started in Germany in 1919 and was closed by the Nazis in 1933. From the 1930s onwards, a significant number of central European, Austrian and German refugees and emigres came to Australia seeking refuge from war and fascism, many of whom were active in arts education. Through these exiles and internees, educational ideas filtered into Australia that revealed the influence of the Bauhaus.

Location: Gallery 1

10am-5pm daily, 10am-7pm Fridays
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City

title: Clock Tower Tour
description:
The Clock Tour Tower is a ‘must-do’ for anyone and everyone in Brisbane! Discover the secrets of the heritage-listed City Hall building with a guided tour.

For many years, City Hall’s Clock Tower made the building the tallest in Brisbane, offering visitors a magnificent 360 degree view of the city around them. Whilst the view has changed significantly over the last 90 years, the time-honoured tradition of “taking a trip up the tower” happily continues at Museum of Brisbane.

The Clock Tower Tour includes a ride in one of Brisbane’s oldest working cage lifts, a look behind Australia’s largest analogue clock faces and time to explore the observation platform that shares a unique perspective of the city. See if you can catch a glimpse of the bells!

Tour begins from Museum of Brisbane reception on Level 3 of City Hall.

Events run every 15 minutes from 10.15am-4.45pm.
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City

title: Stories Around the Riverbend Tour
description:
Looping from City Hall to the banks of the Brisbane River and back, this guided walk explores many facets of Brisbane’s history. On your way to the river, you will stop at the historic Regent Theatre and Tattersall’s Club in the Queen Street Mall, before heading to MacArthur Chambers, used by General Douglas MacArthur as his headquarters during World War II. and on to St Stephen’s Cathedral.

In Naldham House, you will hear tales of the devastating floods of 1893, which claimed 35 lives and left 10,000 people homeless. From the riverfront at Eagle Street Pier, gaze across to the remarkable Kangaroo Point Cliffs and iconic Story Bridge. Creek Street then leads back to Anzac Square, and the grand edifice of Central Station. From there, stop off at two of Brisbane’s historic churches – Ann Street Presbyterian and Albert Street Uniting – before completing your loop walk at City Hall.

Location: Tour begins in King George Square outside entrance to Brisbane City Hall.

Time: Tours may extend beyond 90 minutes

Distance: 2 kilometres
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City
eventBookingSite: Find out more and book via the Museum of Brisbane website.

title: Journey to City Botanic Gardens tour
description:
Starting at City Hall, this guided walking tour takes you past many of the convict sites linked to the gardens’ early beginnings.

Established in 1828 to provide food for the Brisbane penal colony, the City Botanic Gardens is the green heart of the city. Starting at Brisbane City Hall, this guided walking tour takes you past many of the convict sites linked to the gardens’ early beginnings, including the barracks for male convicts, as well as the historic George Street strip (lookup for the gargoyles on the old Printery Building). Hear the stories of those who lived here, before reaching Parliament House and Old Government House.

In the botanic gardens, learn how the city’s magnificent spring jacaranda displays began with the planting of Australia’s first jacaranda tree here in 1864 by the gardens’ first curator, Walter Hill. Returning to the street, hear the history of the Commissariat Store, one of only two surviving convict-built structures in Brisbane, of the city’s first pedestrian river crossing, the Victoria Bridge, and of pioneering women’s activist Emma Miller.

Location: Tour begins in King George Square outside entrance to Brisbane City Hall.

Time: Tours may extend beyond 90 minutes.

Distance: 2.5 kilometres.
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City
eventBookingSite: Bookings required via Museum of Brisbane website.

title: Lights On: QMusic
description:
Bask in exclusive new works developed by leading Brisbane companies and creative artists emerging from isolation.

Lights On at Brisbane Powerhouse is a curated series of bespoke shows; a limited season created for small audiences and a re-imagined venue.

Songs From Your Shutdown features iconic Brisbane singer-songwriter Robert Forster (The Go-Betweens) hosting an evening with Darren Hanlon, Sycco and Minor Premiers to share their stories and songs created during lockdown.

Presented with QMusic, hear the music and stories that represent the highlights, low-lights and late nights of self-isolation as these artists plug back in and reconnect for this unique performance.  

Be the first to experience the buzz of live performance again. It’s time to reconnect and shine a light on our extraordinary local arts community.

Celebrate our reopening and make the most of your night out by enjoying a cabaret platter for two and a bottle of wine, bubbles or champagne while you enjoy the performance.

title: Bauhaus Now: art+design+architecture
description:
**This event has been cancelled.** Bauhaus Now brings to life the little-known story of how revolutionary ideas of the Weimar Republic in Germany influenced modernist art, design and architecture in Brisbane and Australia. The exhibition reveals the migrant and refugee contribution to Australian life and art history in the inter-war period and post-Second World War years.

The famous Bauhaus school started in Germany in 1919 and was closed by the Nazis in 1933. From the 1930s onwards, a significant number of central European, Austrian and German refugees and emigres came to Australia seeking refuge from war and fascism, many of whom were active in arts education. Through these exiles and internees, educational ideas filtered into Australia that revealed the influence of the Bauhaus.

Location: Gallery 1

10am-5pm daily, 10am-7pm Fridays

title: Clock Tower Tour
description:
The Clock Tour Tower is a ‘must-do’ for anyone and everyone in Brisbane! Discover the secrets of the heritage-listed City Hall building with a guided tour.

For many years, City Hall’s Clock Tower made the building the tallest in Brisbane, offering visitors a magnificent 360 degree view of the city around them. Whilst the view has changed significantly over the last 90 years, the time-honoured tradition of “taking a trip up the tower” happily continues at Museum of Brisbane.

The Clock Tower Tour includes a ride in one of Brisbane’s oldest working cage lifts, a look behind Australia’s largest analogue clock faces and time to explore the observation platform that shares a unique perspective of the city. See if you can catch a glimpse of the bells!

Tour begins from Museum of Brisbane reception on Level 3 of City Hall.

Events run every 15 minutes from 10.15am-4.45pm.

title: Flowers in ink: reconnect to nature through drawing in the gardens with Michelle Pujol
description:
Join artist-in-residence, Michelle Pujol as she explores the concept of a daily creative practice through ink line drawing of botanical forms as a way to reconnect to nature.

Through her design journals (a daily practice of sketching and observing the flora around her), Michelle will show workshop participants examples of the application of line drawing in her jewellery design and painting, as well as other applications. Participants will then be encouraged to draw in the gardens with Michelle.

Michelle believes that drawing plants is a great way to reconnect to nature whilst still being able to practice your skills - whether you are a beginner or a skilled artisan. Line drawing in ink teaches observation skills and gives you the confidence to start a daily/weekly visual journal and enjoy the relaxation benefits of sketching.

Important information for participants
All materials supplied. A part of this workshop will be held outdoors. Be sun smart and bring a fold-up chair. Part of the workshop is over lunch so feel free to pack a light portable lunch.  Participants are welcome to bring their own visual diaries/ journals and materials if they wish.

Social distancing will be applied during this workshop. If you feel unwell on the day of the program, please do not attend this workshop.

More about Michelle Pujol
Michelle Pujol artworks focus on a number of media including sculptural silver jewellery which she refers to as 'seeds to silver' and her watercolour illustration and traditional oils which she refers to as 'petals to paint'. All have a focus on design as a process. Find out more about the artist-in-residence program in the gardens.

Location: Auditorium
eventVenuMapLink: Brisbane Botanic Gardens Mt Coot-tha, 152 Mt Coot-tha Road, Toowong
eventBookingSite: Bookings required. This workshop is limited to 12 participants. Book by phoning 07 3403 2535.

title: Stories Around the Riverbend Tour
description:
Looping from City Hall to the banks of the Brisbane River and back, this guided walk explores many facets of Brisbane’s history. On your way to the river, you will stop at the historic Regent Theatre and Tattersall’s Club in the Queen Street Mall, before heading to MacArthur Chambers, used by General Douglas MacArthur as his headquarters during World War II. and on to St Stephen’s Cathedral.

In Naldham House, you will hear tales of the devastating floods of 1893, which claimed 35 lives and left 10,000 people homeless. From the riverfront at Eagle Street Pier, gaze across to the remarkable Kangaroo Point Cliffs and iconic Story Bridge. Creek Street then leads back to Anzac Square, and the grand edifice of Central Station. From there, stop off at two of Brisbane’s historic churches – Ann Street Presbyterian and Albert Street Uniting – before completing your loop walk at City Hall.

Location: Tour begins in King George Square outside entrance to Brisbane City Hall.

Time: Tours may extend beyond 90 minutes

Distance: 2 kilometres
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City
eventBookingSite: Find out more and book via the Museum of Brisbane website.

title: Stories Around the Riverbend Tour
description:
Looping from City Hall to the banks of the Brisbane River and back, this guided walk explores many facets of Brisbane’s history. On your way to the river, you will stop at the historic Regent Theatre and Tattersall’s Club in the Queen Street Mall, before heading to MacArthur Chambers, used by General Douglas MacArthur as his headquarters during World War II. and on to St Stephen’s Cathedral.

In Naldham House, you will hear tales of the devastating floods of 1893, which claimed 35 lives and left 10,000 people homeless. From the riverfront at Eagle Street Pier, gaze across to the remarkable Kangaroo Point Cliffs and iconic Story Bridge. Creek Street then leads back to Anzac Square, and the grand edifice of Central Station. From there, stop off at two of Brisbane’s historic churches – Ann Street Presbyterian and Albert Street Uniting – before completing your loop walk at City Hall.

Location: Tour begins in King George Square outside entrance to Brisbane City Hall.

Time: Tours may extend beyond 90 minutes

Distance: 2 kilometres
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City
eventBookingSite: Find out more and book via the Museum of Brisbane website.

title: Bush Kindy - 'Lenny and the Ants' storytime
description:
Lenny and the Ants is a fun story for children of all ages.  Go on a journey with Lenny the Roo to discover a whole new way to think about food.  Written by Jessica Chapnik Kahn, with fun illustrations by Matthew Martin, Lenny and the Ants helps us think about food in different, creative ways. It's estimated that one third of all food produced is lost or wasted. So don't forget to check out the recipes at the back of the book to find out what you can make with those floppy carrots at the bottom of the fridge.

All children must be accompanied by an adult. Wear a wide-brimmed hat, secure, fully enclosed walking shoes, sun-smart clothing, sunscreen and insect repellent. Bring drinking water and a snack or picnic lunch as there are no food outlets on site.

Note: Any walks or outside activities are subject to weather and environmental conditions and may be cancelled on the day.

You will be introduced to all that is on offer at the Museum of Brisbane, meandering through all exhibition spaces and soaking up our heritage-listed home. title: Bauhaus Now: art+design+architecture
description:
**This event has been cancelled.** Bauhaus Now brings to life the little-known story of how revolutionary ideas of the Weimar Republic in Germany influenced modernist art, design and architecture in Brisbane and Australia. The exhibition reveals the migrant and refugee contribution to Australian life and art history in the inter-war period and post-Second World War years.

The famous Bauhaus school started in Germany in 1919 and was closed by the Nazis in 1933. From the 1930s onwards, a significant number of central European, Austrian and German refugees and emigres came to Australia seeking refuge from war and fascism, many of whom were active in arts education. Through these exiles and internees, educational ideas filtered into Australia that revealed the influence of the Bauhaus.

Location: Gallery 1

10am-5pm daily, 10am-7pm Fridays
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City
eventBookingSite: This event has been cancelled.

title: Clock Tower Tour
description:
The Clock Tour Tower is a ‘must-do’ for anyone and everyone in Brisbane! Discover the secrets of the heritage-listed City Hall building with a guided tour.

For many years, City Hall’s Clock Tower made the building the tallest in Brisbane, offering visitors a magnificent 360 degree view of the city around them. Whilst the view has changed significantly over the last 90 years, the time-honoured tradition of “taking a trip up the tower” happily continues at Museum of Brisbane.

The Clock Tower Tour includes a ride in one of Brisbane’s oldest working cage lifts, a look behind Australia’s largest analogue clock faces and time to explore the observation platform that shares a unique perspective of the city. See if you can catch a glimpse of the bells!

Tour begins from Museum of Brisbane reception on Level 3 of City Hall.

Events run every 15 minutes from 10.15am-4.45pm.
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City

title: Museum highlights tour
description:
**Museum highlights tours are temporarily postponed.** Not sure what you are looking at when you wander into the Museum? Let our experienced guide walk you through the current exhibitions and give you an insider’s view and perspective.

An oasis in the heart of the city, Museum of Brisbane is a place to learn and discover the stories of Brisbane.

You will be introduced to all that is on offer at the Museum of Brisbane, meandering through all exhibition spaces and soaking up our heritage-listed home. You will experience the people, places and stories of Brisbane presented through an innovative mix of social history and visual contemporary arts.

On the tours you will be guided by one of our experienced guides, exploring our current exhibitions and discussing the events, tours and workshops available for you to discover more about Brisbane.

This is a free event and there is no need to book, just take the lifts to level three of City Hall and register at Museum Reception.

description: Where is the edge of darkness? Narrated by Hayley Atwell. Approx. 35 minutes, inclusive of night sky tour.

title: Bauhaus Now: art+design+architecture
description:
**This event has been cancelled.** Bauhaus Now brings to life the little-known story of how revolutionary ideas of the Weimar Republic in Germany influenced modernist art, design and architecture in Brisbane and Australia. The exhibition reveals the migrant and refugee contribution to Australian life and art history in the inter-war period and post-Second World War years.

The famous Bauhaus school started in Germany in 1919 and was closed by the Nazis in 1933. From the 1930s onwards, a significant number of central European, Austrian and German refugees and emigres came to Australia seeking refuge from war and fascism, many of whom were active in arts education. Through these exiles and internees, educational ideas filtered into Australia that revealed the influence of the Bauhaus.

Location: Gallery 1

10am-5pm daily, 10am-7pm Fridays
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City
eventBookingSite: This event has been cancelled.

title: Clock Tower Tour
description:
The Clock Tour Tower is a ‘must-do’ for anyone and everyone in Brisbane! Discover the secrets of the heritage-listed City Hall building with a guided tour.

For many years, City Hall’s Clock Tower made the building the tallest in Brisbane, offering visitors a magnificent 360 degree view of the city around them. Whilst the view has changed significantly over the last 90 years, the time-honoured tradition of “taking a trip up the tower” happily continues at Museum of Brisbane.

The Clock Tower Tour includes a ride in one of Brisbane’s oldest working cage lifts, a look behind Australia’s largest analogue clock faces and time to explore the observation platform that shares a unique perspective of the city. See if you can catch a glimpse of the bells!

Tour begins from Museum of Brisbane reception on Level 3 of City Hall.

Events run every 15 minutes from 10.15am-4.45pm.
eventVenuMapLink: Museum of Brisbane, Brisbane City Hall, 64 Adelaide Street, Brisbane City
eventBookingSite: Book online via Eventbrite. There are a maximum of three people per tour.

title: Ben Ely and Ozzy Wrong - Rainbow Armageddon
description:
It’s time to come out of hibernation, Brisbane.

We’ve welcomed back some theatre and your favourite restaurants, now it’s time to reinvigorate the walls of Brisbane Powerhouse with an exhibition featuring not one, but two fantastic artists to get your art show fix (socially distanced of course). 

Rainbow Armageddon will showcase some fresh artworks from Regurgitator’s Ben Ely and Pro surfer and Goons of Doom member, Ozzy Wrong. Each artist brings their distinctive style and character to the Brisbane Powerhouse walls as we come together again to celebrate the venue reopening after those long, dormant months. 

Location: Exhibition Spaces

Times: Wednesdays-Sundays only from 11.30am-5.30pm each day
